greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Largest divisor of n such that all its prime factors are less than the square of the smallest prime factor of n, a(1) = 1.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10001
example: For n = 50 = 2*5*5, only prime less than 2^2 is 2, thus a(50) = 2.
For n = 90 = 2*3*3*5, the primes less than 2^2 are 2, 3 and 3, thus a(90) = 2*3*3 = 18.
mathematica: Table[If[n == 1, 1, Function[d, First[Select[Reverse@ First@ d, Times @@ Boole@ Map[# < Last[d]^2 &, FactorInteger[#][[All, 1]]] == 1 &] /. {} -> {1}]]@ {#, First@ Select[#, PrimeQ]} &@ Divisors@ n], {n, 102}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 24 2017 *)
program: A(n) = if(n<2, return(1), my(f=factor(n)[, 1]); for(i=2, #f, if(f[i]>f[1]^2, return(f[i]))); return(1));
for(n=1, 150, print1(n/a(n),", ")) \\ _Indranil Ghosh_, after _David A. Corneth_, Mar 24 2017
def a(n): return 1 if A(n)==1 else A(n)*a(n//A(n))
print([n//a(n) for n in range(1, 151)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 24 2017
xref: Differs from A284253 for the first time at n=50, where a(50) = 2, while A284253(50) = 10.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 24 2017
